text: EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF THE PRESIDENT
label: TITLE

text: COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISERS
label: BODY

text: WASHINGTON, D.C.
label: BODY

text: This technical memo describes the likely economic impacts on the local economy of the
label: BODY

text: purchase and modification of the state prison in Thomson, Illinois and its subsequent use by the
label: BODY

text: Department of Defense (DoD) and the Bureau of Prisons (BoP) as a federal facility.  This memo
label: BODY

text: assumes that BoP occupies 75% of the facility and DoD occupies the remaining 25%. The
label: BODY

text: primary estimates are:
label: BODY

text: 1. The total increase in expenditures in the area over the first four years of
label: BODY

text: operation through construction, operation costs, compensation, and visitors to the
label: BODY

text: area is between $0.9 billion and $1.1 billion.
label: BODY

text: 2. In the first year, the modification, opening, and running of the facility will
label: BODY

text: generate between 2,290 and 2,960 jobs in the seven-county area.  Local residents
label: BODY

text: will be excellent candidates for 1,240 to 1,410 of these jobs.  The other jobs will
label: BODY

text: be filled by people relocating to the area.  In this first year, total earnings will
label: BODY

text: increase by between $131 million and $185 million.
label: BODY

text: 3. In the second year, the operation of the facility will generate between 2,820 and
label: BODY

text: 3,520 jobs in the seven-county area.  By the third year, when the BoP facility is
label: BODY

text: fully operational, the facility will generate between 3,170 and 3,870 jobs in the
label: BODY

text: seven-county area.  Local residents will be excellent candidates for 1,720 to 1,920
label: BODY

text: of these on-going jobs generated by the facility.  By the third year, earnings will
label: BODY

text: increase by between $233 and $289 million, relative to current levels.
label: BODY

text: 4.  The ongoing increase in employment reflects jobs created by yearly capital
label: BODY

text: improvements (490-560 jobs), direct hires (1,900-2,400 jobs), jobs created by
label: BODY

text: visitors to the area (280 jobs), and indirect jobs due to increased spending and
label: BODY

text: economic activity (510-640 jobs by the fourth year).  In addition, start-up costs
label: BODY

text: that occur in both the first and second year as well as one-time construction costs
label: BODY

text: generate a substantial number of year-long jobs (840-910 jobs).
label: BODY

text: 5. Over the first four years, the 840 - 910 temporary jobs and the eventual 3,180 -
label: BODY

text: 3,880 ongoing jobs generated by the facility are expected to increase local
label: BODY

text: earnings by a cumulative $793 to $1,015 million.
label: BODY

text: 6. Approximately 80% of all of the jobs created by the facility will be held by
label: BODY

text: people residing in Illinois, while people in Iowa will fill the remaining jobs. These
label: BODY

text: jobs could reduce the unemployment rate in Carroll County, Illinois, where
label: BODY

text: Thomson is located, by 2 to 4 percentage points.
label: BODY

text: The remainder of the memo provides background and explains these estimates.
label: BODY

text: I. Background on the Local Economy
label: HH1

text: The local economy consists of seven counties.  First is Carroll County, where Thomson is
label: HH1

text: located.  Four other counties in Illinois with major population centers within a little over one
label: BODY

text: hour drive from Thomson, Illinois are also included: Whiteside County, Jo Daviess County, Lee
label: BODY

text: County, and Rock Island County.  In particular, Rock Island has a relatively large population and
label: BODY

text: a military installation, so spillover effects from the Thomson facility are expected.  The local
label: BODY

text: economy also includes Clinton County and Jackson County in Iowa, which have cities nearby.
label: BODY

text: The economies of the Illinois counties are distressed.  The September 2009 unemployment
label: HH1

text: rate for Carroll County was 10.5%.  The comparable rates for Whiteside County, Lee County,
label: BODY

text: and Rock Island County were 10.6%, 10.9%, and 9.5% respectively.  The unemployment rate in
label: BODY

text: Jo Daviess County was a more modest 8.1% in September, but this rate is up from 5.1% a year
label: BODY

text: earlier.  In addition, the fraction of adults in Carroll County that have a college degree is about
label: BODY

text: one-half of the national rate, which poses a challenge in today’s economy that increasingly
label: BODY

text: requires higher education for good jobs.
label: BODY

text: Nearby counties in Iowa appear to be less economically distressed.  For example, the
label: HH1

text: September 2009 unemployment rates for nearby Iowa counties, Clinton County and Jackson
label: BODY

text: County, were both 7.7%.  Nonetheless, per capita income in these counties was under 85% of
label: BODY

text: national per capita income in the latest data (average from 2006 to 2008).1
label: BODY

text: Carroll County has capacity to absorb new economic activity.   In a population of roughly
label: HH1

text: 16,000 people, the BLS estimates that 840 people are currently unemployed.  In addition, there
label: BODY

text: are 3 industrial buildings, 7 building sites, 5 retail buildings, 13 commercial buildings, and 2
label: BODY

text: other buildings for sale in Carroll County.2  The county has at least 18 hotels, motels, and the
label: BODY

text: like with at least 250 beds.3
label: BODY

text: The other counties in Illinois and Clinton County and Jackson County in Iowa also have
label: HH1

text: capacity to absorb new economic activity.  We estimate that nearly 17,000 people are currently
label: HH1

text: unemployed in these six counties.  As mentioned above, commuting times from the largest
label: BODY

text: population centers in these counties to Thomson, Illinois range from 20 minutes to a little over
label: BODY

text: one hour.4  Thus, it is likely that people in these counties will be willing to work in Thomson and
label: BODY

text: its environs.  In addition, these six counties have at least 170 hotels, motels, and the like.5
label: BODY

text: II. Description of Facility
label: HH1

text: The opening of the facility will have a large and immediate direct effect on the local
label: HH1

text: economy.  BoP expects to occupy 75% of the facility, and DoD will occupy the remaining 25%.
label: BODY

text: In essence, DoD and BoP will operate two entirely separate facilities side by side.  DoD expects
label: BODY

text: 1 Unemployment estimates come from the Local Area Unemployment Statistics BLS survey. Education statistic is
label: BODY

text: from the 2000 Census. Per capita income is from the 2006-2008 American Community Survey.
label: BODY

text: 2 Information from the Carroll County Economic Development Corporation website
label: BODY

text: (http://www.carrollcountyedc.org/index.php?module=cdc&ff_op=view&MMN_position=26:26).
label: BODY

text: 3 Information from http://www.gocarrollcounty.com/lodging.html.
label: BODY

text: 4 We used Google Maps to estimate driving time.
label: BODY

text: 5 These estimates come from local tourism websites in the counties and conversations with county tourism offices.
label: BODY

text: to spend $35 to $40 million on capital improvements to open the facility; DoD expects to make a
label: BODY

text: similar amount of capital improvements in subsequent years as well.  BoP expects to spend $15
label: BODY

text: million on construction to modify the prison and $22 million on furnishings, equipment, and
label: BODY

text: supplies.  Both of these are one-time expenditures by BoP.6  In addition, BoP expects to spend
label: BODY

text: $85,000 per employee who has to be relocated from another facility.  Part of this $85,000 is an
label: BODY

text: allowance for housing and other living expenses given to relocating workers for a short period
label: BODY

text: after moving.  This part, which is spent locally, is included in this analysis as it creates local
label: BODY

text: jobs.7
label: BODY

text: III. Estimating the Economic Impact
label: HH1

text: A. Assumptions
label: BODY

text: The estimated economic impacts rely on several assumptions.  For its portion of the facility,
label: BODY

text: DoD provided the following assumptions:
label: BODY

text: 1. DoD anticipates total staffing needs of between 1,000 and 1,500 employees.
label: BODY

text: One-third of these employees will be government civilian employees or
label: BODY

text: private contractors with annual salaries between $80,000 and $90,000.  The
label: BODY

text: other two-thirds of the employees will be military personnel, with salaries of
label: BODY

text: $65,000, which includes a housing allowance.
label: BODY

text: 2. DoD expects that military personnel will not relocate their families during the
label: BODY

text: facility’s first year.  As a result, spending by military personnel is expected to
label: BODY

text: be 25% of typical employees’ spending initially.  After the facility is open one
label: BODY

text: year, this percentage is expected to rise to 75%.
label: BODY

text: 3. DoD expects few of its direct hires to come from the local communities.
label: BODY

text: 4. DoD expects to make $35 to $40 million of capital improvements annually,
label: BODY

text: matching the current annual expenditures on improvements at the facility in
label: BODY

text: Guantanamo Bay.
label: BODY

text: For its portion of the facility, BoP provided the following assumptions:
label: BODY

text: 1. BoP anticipates total staffing needs of 448 correctional officers and 448
label: BODY

text: medical personnel, food service workers, and other staff workers.8
label: BODY

text: 2. BoP expects to hire 150 workers over the course of the first year (with 50 of
label: BODY

text: these hires from the local community).  The average workforce during the
label: BODY

text: year will be about 70 workers.  Over the course of the second year, BoP will
label: BODY

text: hire the remaining 746 workers (with 398 of these hires from the local area).
label: BODY

text: On average, BoP will directly employ 600 workers in the second year.
label: BODY

text: 3. Annual salaries will increase over time.  Correctional officers will have an
label: BODY

text: annual salary in the first year, including benefits, of $82,000.  This salary will
label: BODY

text: 6 These and other estimates relating to the expenditures  necessary to open and operate the facility come directly
label: BODY

text: from DoD and BoP.  The analysis of the economic impact presented in this memo relies directly on these estimates.
label: BODY

text: 7 In addition, BoP will spend $3,500 on background checks for each employee, those relocating and those who are
label: BODY

text: local.  No part of these expenditures are reflected in this analysis, as this spending will not occur locally.
label: BODY

text: 8 Following a recent analysis, BoP plans call for its portion of the facility to be a higher-security prison with 2000
label: BODY

text: inmates.
label: BODY

text: rise to $92,300 by the fourth year.  Other staff will have an annual salary in
label: BODY

text: the first year of $93,000.  This salary will rise to $104,000 by the fourth year.9
label: BODY

text: 4. In the first year, salaries will total nearly $6 million, and by year 2, salary
label: BODY

text: costs will rise to $55 million as BoP ramps up its staffing.  By year 3, salaries
label: BODY

text: total $85 million.
label: BODY

text: In total, BoP expects to hire 448 workers locally.  This could be achieved by hiring about
label: BODY

text: 2.5% of the estimated 17,700 unemployed people in the seven-county region.10  In light
label: BODY

text: of the high rates of unemployment, it may be possible to hire a greater fraction of the
label: BODY

text: staff from local residents.  Jobs indirectly created by the opening of the facility, described
label: BODY

text: below, will be most likely filled by the local community.
label: BODY

text: We made the additional assumptions to compute the economic impact to the local communities:
label: BODY

text: 1. We assume 40% of the economic impact will be concentrated in Carroll
label: BODY

text: County, where Thomson is located.  In light of the populations of the
label: BODY

text: remaining six counties and their proximity to Thomson, 40% of the impact
label: BODY

text: will occur in the other Illinois counties and the remaining 20% will occur in
label: BODY

text: the two Iowa counties.
label: BODY

text: 2. DoD expects that their portion of the facility will bring in roughly 200 outside
label: BODY

text: visitors who will be present at any point in time.  These visitors will be
label: BODY

text: attorneys, diplomatic officials, law enforcement officials, delegates from the
label: BODY

text: International Committee of the Red Cross, as well as journalists.11    We use
label: BODY

text: the Federal per diem rate to estimate that these visitors in the area on business
label: BODY

text: will directly inject $11 million annually into the local economy.  These
label: BODY

text: expenditures will largely be concentrated in lodging, food, and local
label: BODY

text: transportation.
label: BODY

text: 3. We assume no visitors to the BoP facility in the first year as BoP starts up
label: BODY

text: operations and then 50 visitors in the second year.  When the BoP facility is
label: BODY

text: fully operational in the third year, 100 outside visitors will be present on any
label: BODY

text: given day, on average.12  These visitors will be family and others visiting the
label: BODY

text: BoP prisoners as well as attorneys and journalists.  We use 50% of the Federal
label: BODY

text: per diem rate for these visitors and estimate that their expenditures will
label: BODY

text: directly inject $3 million annually into the local economy.
label: BODY

text: 4. The portion of the BoP relocation allowance used for temporary living
label: BODY

text: expenses for relocated workers is assumed to be spent at 100% of the Federal
label: BODY

text: per diem rate on housing, food, and transportation.  The effects of these
label: BODY

text: 9 In computing the economic impact of these rising salaries, we restrict ourselves to looking at the real increase, after
label: BODY

text: accounting for inflation.  We assume an inflation rate of 2% in each of the next four years.  Other expenditures show
label: BODY

text: no growth after accounting for inflation.
label: BODY

text: 10 Unemployment estimates come from the Local Area Unemployment Statistics BLS survey.
label: BODY

text: 11 Unlike BoP, DoD does not allow family or personal visits for its detainees.  This has been the policy at
label: BODY

text: Guantanamo Bay, and it will continue as the policy in the United States.
label: BODY

text: 12 This is somewhat higher than the number of people visiting an average U.S. penitentiary on an average day.
label: BODY

text: However, the BoP portion of the facility is considerably larger than the average penitentiary, and our figure also
label: BODY

text: includes people visiting the local area accompanying those visiting the facility.
label: BODY

text: temporary payments are categorized as “start-up” effects for the purposes of
label: BODY

text: Table 1 (on page 6).
label: BODY

text: B. Impact on Economy of Carroll County and Surrounding Area
label: BODY

text: The opening of the prison will have a direct effect on the local economy as workers are hired to
label: BODY

text: modify the facility and provide necessary supplies.    As mentioned above, BoP will spend $37
label: BODY

text: million on construction and initial supply costs.  In addition, BoP estimates that annual operating
label: BODY

text: costs will be $24 million in the second year and $37 million by year three.  DoD estimates
label: BODY

text: annual operating costs between $40 and $50 million.  Construction activity will generate local
label: BODY

text: jobs.  In addition, some of the inputs purchased by BoP and DoD to start up and for ongoing
label: BODY

text: operations will be produced by the local economy, creating local jobs.
label: BODY

text: Finally, a large share of the new salaries will go to purchase goods and services produced in the
label: BODY

text: local area as employees spend part of their salaries in the local economy.  For example, DoD
label: BODY

text: personnel will use their salaries to consume locally-provided goods and services, such as
label: BODY

text: housing, retail goods, and health care.   This will provide additional income for landlords, shop
label: BODY

text: keepers, and nurses and these people will, in turn, spend some of their additional income in the
label: BODY

text: local community.  Workers hired to complete construction work will also spend a portion of their
label: BODY

text: salaries locally.  These indirect waves of economic activity will amplify the direct impacts of the
label: BODY

text: facility and help reduce unemployment in these counties.
label: BODY

text: In sum, we estimate that the total increase in area expenditures resulting from the opening
label: HH1

text: and running of the facility over the first four years of operation through construction
label: HH1

text: expenditures, operation costs, salaries (including the portion of the relocation allowance
label: HH1

text: spent locally), and visitors to the area will be between $0.9 and $1.1 billion.13
label: HH1

text: To quantify the full effect of these expenditures on the local economy, we used the Regional
label: BODY

text: Input-Output Modeling System (RIMS II) from the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA).  This
label: BODY

text: model has been in use since the 1980s and is designed to answer questions exactly like the one at
label: BODY

text: hand.  It quantifies the impact from spending in various economic sectors on local economic
label: BODY

text: activity and employment.14  Specifically, it produces multipliers that capture the direct and
label: BODY

text: indirect effect of industry-specific spending on output and jobs.
label: BODY

text: There are several attractive features of the RIMS II model.  It accounts for the regional
label: BODY

text: distribution of inputs purchased and outputs sold in each affected industry and for the typical
label: BODY

text: spending patterns of the new employees.  A key additional feature of RIMS II is that it accounts
label: BODY

text: for the degree of “earnings leakage” that results when individuals purchase goods that are
label: BODY

text: produced outside the local economy or region.
label: BODY

text: At the same time, input-output models, of which RIMS II is an example, have some limitations.
label: BODY

text: Input-output models are more appropriate for smaller fiscal changes, such as the one being
label: BODY

text: considered here, than broadly-based fiscal expansion, such as estimating the impact of the
label: BODY

text: American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.  In general, when used to estimate the
label: BODY

text: 13 The figure takes into account the growth in salaries over time after adjusting for inflation.
label: BODY

text: 14 See http://www.bea.gov/regional/rims/brfdesc.cfm for a description of the model’s methodology and accuracy.
label: BODY

text: effects of broadly-based fiscal expansion, input-output models yield substantially higher jobs
label: BODY

text: estimates than more aggregated macroeconomic models.  This difference may be explained by
label: BODY

text: aggregated macroeconomic models accounting for partially offsetting declines to employment in
label: BODY

text: other regions.  However, the difference could also suggest that input-output models may tend to
label: BODY

text: yield somewhat optimistic estimates.  This difference is explored at this end of this memo.
label: BODY

text: Table 1 reports that the seven-county area is expected to experience an estimated increase
label: HH1

text: in employment of between 2,290 and 2,960 jobs in the first year as a result of the
label: BODY

text: construction, start up, and running of the facility.  These figures capture the workers who are
label: HH1

text: directly employed by the facility, as well the indirect employment effect brought about by the
label: BODY

text: workers’ earnings.  Many of the 780 to 850 jobs resulting from the opening of the facility will be
label: BODY

text: related to construction, and qualified local residents will be excellent candidates for these jobs, as
label: BODY

text: construction contractors prefer to avoid the expense of bringing in outside workers.  Outside of
label: BODY

text: construction, the start-up jobs result from BoP’s expenditures on furnishings, equipment, and
label: BODY

text: supplies as well as the relocation allowance spent by relocating workers.
label: BODY

text: The remaining employment reflects 1,070 to 1,570 direct hires, 220 jobs created by those
label: BODY

text: traveling on business to the DoD portion of the facility, and between 220 and 310 indirect jobs
label: BODY

text: due to increased spending by the direct hires in the area.  Overall, current local residents will be
label: BODY

text: excellent candidates for 1,240 to 1,410 of these jobs.  Altogether, these jobs will produce a total
label: BODY

text: of between $131 million and $185 million in local earnings in the first year.
label: BODY

text: The second panel of the table reports that in the second year, the facility will generate an
label: BODY

text: estimated total of between 2,820 and 3,520 jobs.  As in the first year, most of these jobs come
label: BODY

text: from the DoD facility, which is expected to ramp up operations more quickly than BoP.  While
label: BODY

text: not reported in this table, the breakdown of jobs generated by the DoD facility in the second year
label: BODY

text: and thereafter is very similar to the first year.  The small increase in the number of jobs in year
label: BODY

text: two is due to the assumption that this is when military personnel are expected to relocate their
label: BODY

text: families and begin spending a greater fraction of their salaries locally.
label: BODY

text: In the second year, the BoP facility is expected to generate 860 jobs.  Of these, 600 are direct
label: BODY

text: hires, 30 are generated by the expected visitors to the area, and the remaining 230 are generated
label: BODY

text: by the relocated direct hires spending their relocation allowance (60 jobs) and all of the direct
label: BODY

text: hires spending a portion of their salaries locally (170 jobs).  BoP expects that all of their
label: BODY

text: construction will be completed in the first year.
label: BODY

text: Table 1: Effect of the Facility on Employment and Earnings
label: BODY

text: Notes: Estimates based on the RIMS II Model, CEA calculations, and information described in the text.  Numbers may not sum due to rounding.
label: BODY

text: In the third year, the facility is expected to generate 3,170 to 3,870 jobs.  Again, the DoD facility
label: BODY

text: generates 1,960 to 2,660 of these jobs.  The jobs generated by the BoP facility rises to 1,210 as
label: BODY

text: the facility is fully staffed, the number of visitors to the area increases to its ongoing level of 100,
label: BODY

text: and the salaries of the direct hires increase.  In the fourth year, the facility is expected to generate
label: BODY

text: 3,180 to 3,890 jobs.  This figure is slightly higher than in the previous year as the BoP direct
label: BODY

text: hires receive real salary increases and their local spending rises.  Altogether, these jobs will
label: BODY

text: produce a total of between $236 million and $292 million in local earnings.
label: BODY

text: Within four years, these jobs generated by the facility will produce a cumulative total of between
label: BODY

text: $793 million and $1,015 million in local earnings.
label: BODY

text: Table 2 estimates the ongoing employment gains by the employees’ state of residence, using the
label: BODY

text: employment effects estimated for the fourth year of operation of the facility.  The ongoing
label: BODY

text: operation of the prison is estimated to generate about 2,820 jobs that will be filled by people
label: BODY

text: residing in Illinois.  Of these, 1,410 jobs are projected to be filled by people residing in Carroll
label: BODY

text: County.
label: BODY

text: Importantly, labor force participation is 63% in Carroll County, according to the most recent data
label: BODY

text: from the 2000 Census.  This level is considerably lower than the average labor force
label: BODY

text: participation rate in Illinois, which was 67% according to the most recent data.15  We assume that
label: BODY

text: the creation of new jobs in the area will pull the labor force participation rate up to the national
label: BODY

text: average, as the returns to work will increase.  This effect is largest in Carroll County, but we also
label: BODY

text: assume that labor force participation rates will rise modestly in Whiteside County and Rock
label: BODY

text: Island County.  After accounting for this increase in the workforce, the increase in employment
label: BODY

text: in Carroll County is expected to lower the unemployment rate by 4 percentage points within four
label: BODY

text: years.  If people move into the area as a result of the facility opening, the unemployment will not
label: BODY

text: fall by as much.  For example, if one-quarter of the relocating direct hires move with  spouses
label: BODY

text: who join the labor force, the unemployment rate in Carroll County will fall by 2 percentage
label: BODY

text: points.  In any case, these new jobs translate into a substantial increase in local earnings.
label: BODY

text: In addition, the facility is estimated to generate about 1,410 jobs filled by people residing in the
label: BODY

text: other counties in Illinois: Whiteside, Jo Daviess, Lee, and Rock Island.  Adding these jobs would
label: BODY

text: reduce the unemployment rate by 1 percentage point.  The expected change in the unemployment
label: BODY

text: rate is larger in Whiteside, Jo Daviess, and Lee County, which are smaller than Rock Island
label: BODY

text: County.  Further, people residing in Clinton and Jackson counties in Iowa are projected to fill
label: BODY

text: 700 jobs together, implying a decline in the unemployment rate by 1 percentage point.
label: BODY

text: Over the longer term, the increased employment opportunities may attract new migrants to the
label: BODY

text: local economy.  These new residents would increase the size of the labor force and put upward
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: pressure on the unemployment rate.  Thus, unemployment rate predictions are most relevant for
label: BODY

text: the medium term.  Regardless, the opening of the facility will lead to a substantial increase in
label: BODY

text: local employment, earnings, and likely in property values as new residents purchase homes.
label: BODY

text: IV. Alternative Methods of Estimating the Economic Impact of Prisons
label: HH1

text: Event Studies.  One alternative approach to estimating the impacts of the prison opening is to
label: HH1

text: turn to the previous literature on prison openings.  Unfortunately, this literature is incomplete and
label: BODY

text: controversial.  Beale (1996) estimates that new non-metro prisons employed approximately 275
label: BODY

text: workers per institution, with the workers “typically drawn from surrounding counties as well as
label: BODY

text: from the host county.”16  The facility discussed in this memo will directly employ many more
label: BODY

text: workers than the average prison considered by Beale.  In the first year, we expect that 1,900 to
label: BODY

text: 2,400 individuals will be directly hired to work at the Thomson facility, more than three times as
label: BODY

text: many as the average facility considered by Beale.  In addition, Beale does not measure indirect
label: BODY

text: effects on employment from increased spending in the area.  Other evidence suggests that the
label: BODY

text: opening of prisons is associated with a growth in public sector employment.17
label: BODY

text: The empirical literature that looks at overall effects from prison openings is complicated by the
label: BODY

text: fact that prison placement is not random; differences in outcomes between places where prisons
label: BODY

text: open and places where prisons do not open could reflect underlying differences between the two
label: BODY

text: communities, rather than the direct effect of prisons themselves.  A number of papers use
label: BODY

text: statistical methods to control for pre-existing differences between communities in local
label: BODY

text: employment, poverty, and housing values.18  These studies provide some suggestive evidence
label: BODY

text: that prison openings may decrease poverty for economically distressed communities.
label: BODY

text: While there are few numerical estimates from these studies, they confirm the essential point that
label: BODY

text: prison openings tend to raise employment and prosperity in the local community.
label: BODY

text: CEA ARRA Methodology.  Another way to check the plausibility of the estimates derived from
label: HH1

text: the BEA’s RIMS II model is to apply the more macroeconomic approach the CEA used for
label: BODY

text: estimating the impact of the ARRA.  Based on estimates from a range of respected
label: BODY

text: macroeconomic forecasting models, the CEA estimated that the cost per job created by direct
label: BODY

text: government investment spending was approximately $92,000 per year.
label: BODY

text: As discussed above, over the first four years of operation, the prison project is estimated to
label: BODY

text: involve expenditures (including construction, operation costs, compensation, and visitors) of
label: BODY

text: between $0.9 and $1.1 billion.  Applying the simple rule of $92,000 per job-year, this level of
label: BODY

text: expenditure suggests total job creation over the four year period of 9,730 to 12,120 job-years.
label: BODY

text: Since this estimate covers a four-year period, it suggests average jobs per year of between 2,430

text: and 3,030.  The comparable estimates based on the RIMS II model are average jobs per year of
label: BODY

text: between 2,860 and 3,550.  In the fourth year, expenditures associated with the operation of the
label: BODY

text: facility total a high of $297 million, at the high end of the range.  Using the same rule of thumb
label: BODY

text: that it takes $92,000 to create a job for one year, this suggests an estimated effect on employment
label: BODY

text: of 3,228 in a typical year, somewhat below the RIMS II employment estimate of 3,880.
label: BODY

text: Overall, the estimates of the two methodologies yield broadly similar employment estimates and
label: BODY

text: the similarity provides support for the credibility of the estimates in Table 1.
